7 women's; 5 men's |colors = [[Purple (color)|Purple]] and [[White]] {{color box|#634298}} {{color box|#FFFFFF}} |nickname = Purple Knights |mascot = Purple Knight |athletics = [[NCAA]] [[Division II (NCAA)|Division II]] |affiliations = [[East Coast Conference|ECC]] |website = [http://www.bridgeport.edu/ www.bridgeport.edu] }} The '''University of Bridgeport''' is a private, independent, non-sectarian, coeducational university located on the [[Long Island Sound]] in the South End neighborhood of [[Bridgeport, Connecticut|Bridgeport]], [[Connecticut]]. The University is fully [[Accredited]] by the [[New England Association of Schools and Colleges]] (NEASC-CIHE).[http://cihe.neasc.org/about_our_institutions/roster_of_institutions/ Roster of Institutions - New England Association of Schools and Colleges: Commission on Institutions of Higher Education (CIHE)] The University is known for its diverse student population, currently ranking as the eleventh most racially diverse national university in the country by ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]''.[http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/national-campus-ethnic-diversity Best Colleges: Racial Diversity: National Universities] â US News & World Report The University School, a high school, is also on the University's grounds. The university had financial troubles in the 1990s and was the subject of controversy when the trustees were obligated to enter into serious negotiations with and subsequently gave control of the institution to the [[Professors World Peace Academy]] (PWPA), an affiliate of the [[Unification Church]], a [[new religious movement]] founded by [[Sun Myung Moon]] in [[Seoul, South Korea]] in 1954, in order to save it from closure.{{cite news | last =Judson | first =George | title =Making the Hard Choice at Bridgeport U.: Opting to Stay Alive | work =[[The New York Times]] | page =B5 | publisher =[[The New York Times Company]] | date = April 17, 1992 | url =http://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/17/nyregion/making-the-hard-choice-at-bridgeport-u-opting-to-stay-alive.html | accessdate = October 6, 2009 }} ==History== ===Founding=== The school was founded in 1927 as the '''Junior College of Connecticut''', under a charter by the state legislature. In 1947 it became the University of Bridgeport, when it gained state authority to grant baccalaureate degrees. The university acquired Arnold College, formerly of Milford, Connecticut, in 1953. ===Expansion and decline=== The University grew rapidly in the 1960s by capitalizing on the increased number of people seeking to attend a U.S. college resulting from the [[baby boom]], [[Vietnam War]] veterans eligible for a higher education under the [[G.I. Bill]], and international students who wanted to attend college in the United States. Enrollment peaked at 9100 students in 1969.Schaffer, Robert ''Illustrated History of Bridgeport'' NY: Wislow Publishing, 1992, p. 52. Enrollment declined in the 1970s and 1980s after the waves of baby boom and Vietnam era veterans eligible for the G.I. Bill declined. By 1990, the University had cut tuition, room and board fees to $18,000 per year, but the school's reputation had not improved. More than a third of the 50 campus buildings were empty. To cut costs, the university decided to terminate 50 tenured faculty, and asked the other faculty to accept a 30% wage cut.Davey, Robert âMoon Over Bridgeportâ ''Connecticut Magazine'' (July, 1994), p. 69 In addition, the University decided to eliminate its liberal arts college, alienating many students.{{cite news | last =Judson | first =George | title =University To Eliminate Liberal Arts | work =[[The New York Times]] | page =B1 | publisher =[[The New York Times Company]] | date =November 27, 1991 | url =http://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/27/nyregion/university-to-eliminate-liberal-arts.html | accessdate = October 6, 2009}} This led to the longest faculty [[strike action|strike]] in the history of American higher education. Dr. Greenwood, the president at the time, quit abruptly, and around 1,000 students left the school, contributing to the cash crisis.{{cite news | last =Judson | first =George | title =Bridgeport U. Nears Accord With Banks | work =[[The New York Times]] | page =B5 | publisher =[[The New York Times Company]] | date =December 24, 1991 | accessdate = October 6, 2009|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/24/nyregion/bridgeport-u-nears-accord-with-banks.html}} ===PWPA and Sun Myung Moon=== In 1990, discussion began about affiliating or possibly merging the University with either the [[University of New Haven]] or [[Sacred Heart University]].{{cite news | last =[[Associated Press]] | title =Merger of New Haven U. and Bridgeport Proposed | work =[[The New York Times]] | page =63, Section: 1 | publisher =[[The New York Times Company]] | date =December 8, 1991 | url =http://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/08/nyregion/merger-of-new-haven-u-and-bridgeport-proposed.html | accessdate = October 6, 2009 }} The University was approached by the [[Professors World Peace Academy]] (PWPA), an affiliate of the [[Unification Church]], but their offer to bail out the University was spurned by the trustees who said the school was "not going to have anything to do with the offer" and were concerned that such an affiliation would damage the University's reputation.{{cite news | last =McQuiston | first =John | title =U. of Bridgeport Refuses Aid From Moon's Group | work =[[The New York Times]] | page =B1 | publisher =[[The New York Times Company]] | date = October 22, 1991 | url =http://www.nytimes.com/1991/10/22/nyregion/u-of-bridgeport-refuses-aid-from-moon-s-group.html | accessdate = October 6, 2009}} Problems continued to plague the University; enrollment fell to 1,300 in 1991. Debt rose to over $22 million in 1991â92. Serious plans to merge the University with Sacred Heart fell through in 1992; the law school instead wanted to associate with [[Quinnipiac University]], but Sacred Heart maintained that any takeover would have to include the law school.{{cite news | last =Judson | first =George | title =University of Bridgeport Plans Takeover by Sacred Heart | work =[[The New York Times]] | page =B4 | publisher =[[The New York Times Company]] | date = January 17, 1992 | url =http://www.nytimes.com/1992/01/17/nyregion/university-of-bridgeport-plans-takeover-by-sacred-heart.html | accessdate = October 6, 2009}} There were other universities willing to take over the school, but were unwilling to take on its debt. The University's charter required the trustees to enter into "serious negotiations", and they accepted the offer, giving the PWPA sixteen spots as trustees, constituting a majority.{{cite news | last =Judson | first =George | title =Bar Group Approves Transfer Of U. of Bridgeport Law School | work =[[The New York Times]] | page =B7 | publisher =[[The New York Times Company]] | date =August 13, 1992 | url =http://www.nytimes.com/1992/08/13/nyregion/bar-group-approves-transfer-of-u-of-bridgeport-law-school.html | accessdate = October 6, 2009 }} The PWPA invested $50.5 million in the university on May 30, 1992,{{cite news | last =The New York Times staff | title =Bridgeport U. Closes Deal to Cede Control | work =[[The New York Times]] | page =25, Section: 1 | publisher =[[The New York Times Company]] | date =May 30, 1992 | url =http://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/30/nyregion/bridgeport-u-closes-deal-to-cede-control.html | accessdate = October 6, 2009 }} enabling the university to keep its accreditation.{{cite news | last =The New York Times staff | title =Bridgeport U. Will Stay Accredited, Official Says | work =[[The New York Times]] | page =28, Section: 1 | publisher =[[The New York Times Company]] | date = June 27, 1992 | url =http://www.nytimes.com/1992/06/27/nyregion/bridgeport-u-will-stay-accredited-official-says.html | accessdate = October 6, 2009 }} A two year faculty strike, started in the midst of the University's financial troubles, intensified when the trustees gave control to the PWPA. Eventually, sixty-six professors and librarians agreed to a "divorce" with the University in return for compensation of up to a year's salary. In a similar move, the law school decided to cut ties with the University, separating from it. In order for the law school to remain open it had to merge with a financially-sound university. The law school faculty and students voted to merge with Quinnipiac University and the name was officially changed to the [[Quinnipiac University School of Law]]. After the PWPA assumed control of the University, the trustees retained the president at the time, Dr. Edwin G. Eigel, Jr. (1932â2008). Eigel served as president till 1995. He was succeeded by distinguished professor and former PWPA president Dr. [[Richard L. Rubenstein]], who served from 1995â1999.[http://www1bpt.bridgeport.edu/~rlr/CVNOT2003-June.htm Richard Rubenstein: A Brief Biographical Note] [[Neil Albert Salonen]], a member of the Unification Church, was the Chairman of the University's Board of Trustees when he was chosen to serve as ninth University president in 1999. He had earlier managed several Unification Church related organizations, and had served as President of the [[Unification Church of the United States]] from 1973 to 1980, and as Chairman of the [[List of Unification Church affiliated organizations|International Cultural Foundation]], prior to becoming the chief executive of the university.[http://www.theamericanchiropractor.com/articledetail.asp?articleid=437&category=21 Featuring Neil Albert Salonen] in ''The American Chiropractor'', July 30, 2005. The University of Bridgeport received funding from the PWPA from 1992 until 2002. In 1995 the University awarded an honorary degree to Moon.[http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60616FA3D550C7B8CDDA00894DD494D81 U. of Bridgeport Honors Rev. Moon, Fiscal Savior], ''[[New York Times]]'', September 8, 1995 Since 2003 the University has been financially independent from PWPA. Members of the Unification Church hold other administrative positions at the University besides the presidency: the University's Board of Trustees includes Gordon L. Anderson and has included [[Chung Hwan Kwak]]. The PWPA considers University of Bridgeport one of its affiliates.http://www.pwpa.org/main/ ==Admissions== Enrollment has grown dramatically in recent years, from 1,383 total students in 1992 to 5,323 students in Fall 2008.[http://www.connpost.com/ci_11022448 Public colleges lead state enrollment rise] ''[[Connecticut Post]]'' November 19, 2008 ==Academics== In its 2011 rankings, University of Bridgeport placed in Tier 2 of National Universities by ''[[U.S. News and World Report]]''. According to the university's website incoming students have an average GPA of 2.8, and an average [[SAT]] score of 1000 (Math and Verbal), 80% go on to get their masters.[http://www.bridgeport.edu/welcome/info/quickfacts.aspx Quick Facts - University of Bridgeport] In its 2006 annual college rankings, ''[[The Washington Monthly]]'' ranked University of Bridgeport 147th of all 245 National universities, with criteria based on research, community service, and social mobility.[http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/features/2006/0609.national.html] The University of Bridgeport is fully [[accredited]] by the [[New England Association of Schools and Colleges]]. The University is also accredited by the Board of Governors of the Connecticut Department of Higher Education.[http://www.bridgeport.edu/welcome/info/accreditation.aspx Accreditations and Memberships - University of Bridgeport] Health Sciences Division: Programs in Chiropractic Medicine, Naturopathic Medicine, Physician Assistant, Human Nutrition, Acupuncture, Dental Hygiene ==Campus safety== The University, in the South End of Bridgeport, has had numerous instances where students' safety and security have been threatened. This is true on campus, but especially in surrounding areas.[Crime Report, https://www.bridgeport.edu/pages/4255.asp] To ameliorate this, the University instituted a program whereby students were issued portable alarm units that pinpoint their position and enable campus security to get to them in under two minutes, earning the school the Jeanne Clery Campus Safety Award.{{cite news | last =Yardley | first =William | title =Does It Work? Campus Security â Finding Safety in Numbers | work =[[The New York Times]] | publisher =[[The New York Times Company]] | date =January 8, 2006 | url =http://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/08/education/edlife/doesitwork_.html | accessdate = October 6, 2009}}[http://www.securityoncampus.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=116&Itemid=76 Jeanne Clery Campus Safety Award Recipients For 2003] Reduced crime has been attributed to increased security on campus, but problems still arise in surrounding areas because relatively few students live on the campus. ==Traditions== ===University Seal=== Bridgeport's seal combines 4 core elements of its traditions and distinct character. In the upper left quadrant, the lamp of learning, which has been an element of the official Bridgeport's seal since 1931, is shown. In the upper right quadrant of the seal, the tree of life is shown, symbolizing personal and institutional growth. The lower left shows Bridgeport's seascape, illustrating the universityâs campus on Long Island Sound.
